questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a recurrent vesicular genital rash comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a painful, pruritic rash that began on the extremities and has spread to her trunk. Her only medication is acyclovir. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Examination of the skin shows several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum is a complication of atopic dermatitis caused by herpes simplex virus infection and typically manifests as a widespread rash with painful, vesicular lesions. This patient does not have a reported history of atopic dermatitis and the target lesions make this an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has erythema multiforme (EM). EM is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain infections (e.g., HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin). EM is characterized by lesions of varying morphology (e.g., macules, papules, vesicles) that typically progress to target lesions and spread proximally from the backs of the hands and feet, as seen here. In EM minor, mucous membranes are not or only minimally involved while in EM major, mucosal involvement occurs. Nikolsky sign is negative and the disease course is self-limiting in most cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

C) INCORRECT:

Urticaria (hives) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that results from IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation. Urticaria is associated with certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and typically manifests as a pruritic, raised erythematous rash. In contrast to the rash seen in this patient, urticaria is typically painless, well-circumscribed, and usually disappears after a few hours.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, lamotrigine) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). SJS can manifest with a painful rash with targetoid lesions, as seen in this patient. However, skin involvement in SJS is typically localized to the face and trunk. Moreover, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of SJS, such as high fever, epidermal detachment with a positive Nikolsky sign, skin necrosis, and involvement of mucous membranes.
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an IgA-mediated skin reaction that is associated with celiac disease and typically manifests as a pruritic, painful papulovesicular rash. However, this patient does not have a history of gluten sensitivity, malabsorption, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Moreover, targetoid skin lesions, which are seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: This patient's rash is most commonly associated with herpes simplex infections and is characterized by target lesions (macules with a dusky center surrounded by a lighter ring).

questions.text: A 14-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 3-day history of a generalized rash and difficulty feeding. The rash started on the hands and feet as small, erythematous papules, before spreading to the entire body. Prior to the onset of the current symptoms, the patient had a 1-week history of mild nonproductive cough. The parents have been giving her dextromethorphan cough syrup at night to help her with the cough. Two months ago, the family visited relatives in the Northeastern US. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 42/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows slightly decreased skin turgor and the findings in the photograph. Examination of the oral cavity discloses erythema and ulceration on the buccal and labial mucosa. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows diffuse reticular opacities in both lungs. Exposure to which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

EM is an acute cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction against antigens deposited in the skin. The condition is most commonly triggered by infections and less commonly caused by certain medications (e.g., sulfonamides, beta-lactam antibiotics) or immunizations. Herpes simplex virus is the most common trigger, but Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection is a significant cause in children. This patient's features of atypical pneumonia (mild respiratory symptoms and diffuse reticular opacities on x-ray) suggest mycoplasma pneumonia. Diagnosis of EM is usually clinical, and most cases are self-limited, only requiring supportive treatment. However, EM major, which manifests with mucous involvement and systemic symptoms, requires hospitalization and is treated similarly to thermal burns. An identified underlying cause of EM should also be treated.

B) INCORRECT:

Food allergens can cause urticaria, which manifests as generalized, raised, well-circumscribed, pruritic, and erythematous papules or plaques. IgE-induced urticaria develops rapidly over minutes to hours and then typically disappears after a few hours, which is not consistent with this patient's rash that has lasted for three days. Furthermore, food allergens are not consistent with this patient's mucosal ulcerations, respiratory symptoms, or findings on chest x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

Medications are responsible for approx. 10% of cases of EM. The most common drugs associated with EM include NSAIDs, beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillins), sulfonamides, and phenytoin. Dextromethorphan cough syrup is not a common trigger, and medication-induced EM is not consistent with this patient's respiratory symptoms or findings on chest x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Ixodes scapulares is a tick that can transmit Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease (LD). LD is endemic in the Northeastern US and can manifest with erythema migrans, an erythematous macule or patch with a central clearing, similar to the target lesions seen here. If left untreated, multiple lesions can occur. However, LD does not affect the oral mucous membranes and is not consistent with this patient's respiratory symptoms or findings on chest x-ray.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is the leading cause of EM, accounting for approx. 50% of all cases. Furthermore, HSV infection can manifest with mucosal ulcerations on the lips and oral cavity. However, HSV infection is not consistent with this patient's respiratory symptoms or findings on chest x-ray. Another cause of EM is more likely to explain this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: The presence of multiple target lesions, consisting of a dusky central area, a surrounding pale zone, and an outer erythematous ring, is characteristic of erythema multiforme (EM).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of a mildly pruritic, slightly tender rash on her hands. She is otherwise healthy and reports no fevers, chills, conjunctival symptoms, or dysuria. She has a temperature of 37.7°C, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 122/81 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute.
Skin examination reveals lesions on both palms (figure). In addition, she has a small, crusted healing lesion on her lower lip.
Which one of the following infections is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Secondary syphilis is often manifested by lesions on the palms, but they are usually ham-colored to violaceous macules, sometimes with a faint scaling, and lack the classic target appearance. The primary chancre is typically painless and can go unnoticed by the patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 reactivation is typically associated with fever; erythematous macules and papules on the trunk and extremities, extending to the face; facial edema; lymphadenopathy; and elevated aminotransferase levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus infection rarely leads to rash in adults but when it does, it is typically a lacy reticulate rash on the thighs.

D) CORRECT:

Target-shaped lesions, which contain three distinct zones of color, are a classic presentation of erythema multiforme. In adults, up to 80% of cases of erythema multiforme are reactions to herpes simplex virus.

Key learning point: Target-shaped lesions on the palms may be a sign of erythema multiforme, which in adults is often associated with infection with herpes simplex virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with acute HIV seroconversion may develop a nonspecific exanthem of diffuse erythematous macules and papules, often with concurrent oral ulcerations. However, no target-shaped lesions would be present on the palms.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 36 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have a painful, itchy rash” 
History of Present Illness:

3-day history of painful, pruritic rash
associated with a “burning” sensation
began on the extremities and has spread to the trunk

Past Medical History:

recurrent vesicular genital rash 
Medications:
acyclovir
Vaccinations:

no known drug allergies

mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions
brother: asthma

school-teacher
lives with her wife
has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 12 years

Skin: several reddish-purple papules and macules, some of which have a dusky center with a lighter ring around them; Nikolsky sign negative 
HEENT: normal oropharynx; pink and moist 
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm, no murmurs
Abdominal: soft and nontender; no organomegaly


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is an IgA-mediated skin reaction that is associated with celiac disease and typically manifests as a pruritic, painful papulovesicular rash. However, this patient does not have a history of gluten sensitivity, malabsorption, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Moreover, targetoid skin lesions, which are seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum is a complication of atopic dermatitis caused by herpes simplex virus infection and typically manifests as a widespread rash with painful, vesicular lesions. This patient does not have a reported history of atopic dermatitis and the target lesions make this an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

C) CORRECT:

This patient with recurrent genital HSV and a painful exanthem with target lesions most likely has erythema multiforme (EM). EM is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain infections (e.g., HSV, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, phenytoin). EM is characterized by lesions of varying morphology (e.g., macules, papules, vesicles) that typically progress to target lesions and spread proximally from the backs of the hands and feet, as seen here. In EM minor, mucous membranes are not or only minimally involved while in EM major, mucosal involvement occurs. Nikolsky sign is negative and the disease course is self-limiting in most cases.
Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction of the skin that can be triggered by certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics, sulfonamides, lamotrigine) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae). SJS can manifest with a painful rash with targetoid lesions, as seen in this patient. However, skin involvement in SJS is typically localized to the face and trunk. Moreover, this patient lacks other characteristic findings of SJS, such as high fever, epidermal detachment with a positive Nikolsky sign, skin necrosis, and involvement of mucous membranes.
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

E) INCORRECT:

Urticaria (hives) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that results from IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation. Urticaria is associated with certain medications (e.g., beta-lactam antibiotics) and infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and typically manifests as a pruritic, raised erythematous rash. In contrast to the rash seen in this patient, urticaria is typically painless, well-circumscribed, and usually disappears after a few hours.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

questions.text: You are seeing a 14-month-old girl who is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 3-day history of generalized rash and difficulty feeding. She had a 1-week history of mild nonproductive cough prior to the onset of her current symptoms. Her parents have been giving her dextromethorphan cough syrup at night for the cough. On examination, there is erythema and ulceration on the buccal and labial mucosa. A photograph of her skin findings is provided. Chest x-ray reveals diffuse reticular opacities in both lungs. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tick bites (e.g., from the Ixodes scapulares tick) can transmit Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease (LD). LD can manifest with erythema migrans, an erythematous macule or patch with a central clearing, similar to the target lesions seen here. If left untreated, multiple lesions can occur. However, LD does not affect the oral mucous membranes and is not consistent with this patient's respiratory symptoms or findings on chest x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic reactions can cause urticaria, which manifests as generalized, raised, well-circumscribed, pruritic, and erythematous papules or plaques. IgE-induced urticaria develops rapidly over minutes to hours and then typically disappears after a few hours, which is not consistent with this patient's rash that has lasted for three days. Furthermore, an allergic reaction is not consistent with this patient's mucosal ulcerations, respiratory symptoms, or findings on chest x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is the leading cause of EM, accounting for approx. 50% of all cases. Furthermore, HSV infection can manifest with mucosal ulcerations on the lips and oral cavity. However, HSV infection is not consistent with this patient's respiratory symptoms or findings on chest x-ray. Another cause of EM is more likely to explain this patient's symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

EM is an acute cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction against antigens deposited in the skin. The condition is most commonly triggered by infections and less commonly caused by certain medications (e.g., sulfonamides, beta-lactam antibiotics) or immunizations. Herpes simplex virus is the most common trigger, but Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection is a significant cause in children. This patient's features of atypical pneumonia (mild respiratory symptoms and diffuse reticular opacities on x-ray) suggest mycoplasma pneumonia. Diagnosis of EM is usually clinical, and most cases are self-limited, only requiring supportive treatment. However, EM major, which manifests with mucous involvement and systemic symptoms, requires hospitalization and is treated similarly to thermal burns. An identified underlying cause of EM should also be treated.

Key learning point: Erythema multiforme is an acute hypersensitivity reaction most often triggered by infections such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae or herpes simplex virus, especially in children.
questions.hint: The presence of multiple target lesions, consisting of a dusky central area, a surrounding pale zone, and an outer erythematous ring, is characteristic of erythema multiforme (EM).

Image Description:

Multiple circular lesions with a central papule and raised edges (also called “target lesions”), surrounded by a lighter edematous area, are visible on the anterior aspect of the thighs.

This is the typical appearance of erythema multiforme.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of skin lesions on her hands and feet that developed after completing a course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. Physical examination shows symmetrically distributed erythematous lesions on the backs of her hands and feet. She has no fever, oral lesions, or ocular symptoms. A photograph of the skin lesions is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with supportive care and follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antifungal therapy is appropriate for the treatment of tinea corporis, but the symmetric distribution of this patient's lesions on the hands and feet with a recent drug exposure suggests a hypersensitivity reaction rather than a dermatophyte infection.

B) INCORRECT:

While dermatology follow-up may be helpful, it is not urgently required for this self-limited condition. The diagnosis can be made clinically in the emergency department with appropriate discharge planning.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is consistent with erythema multiforme minor, which is a self-limited condition that typically resolves within a month with supportive care. The absence of mucosal involvement and systemic symptoms allows for outpatient management with close follow-up.

D) INCORRECT:

IV corticosteroids are not indicated for uncomplicated erythema multiforme minor. Systemic steroids are reserved for severe cases with extensive mucosal involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Ophthalmology consultation is indicated for patients with ocular symptoms or signs of Stevens-Johnson syndrome. This patient does not have ocular symptoms or mucosal involvement, making ophthalmology consultation unnecessary.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of fever and rash that began 3 weeks after starting phenytoin. She appears ill with facial edema and cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination reveals a generalized morbilliform rash covering 60% of her body surface area. Laboratory studies show: WBC 12,800/mm3 with 15% eosinophils, hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL, platelets 145,000/mm3, AST 128 U/L, ALT 156 U/L, and creatinine 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate drug hypersensitivity reactions typically occur within 1 hour of drug exposure and manifest with urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, or anaphylaxis. The delayed onset of 3 weeks and presence of facial edema with organ involvement are not consistent with immediate hypersensitivity reactions.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – DRESS syndrome is characterized by delayed onset 2-8 weeks after drug exposure, fever, diffuse morbilliform rash, facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and internal organ involvement. Facial edema is a common feature of DRESS that is not typically seen in other severe cutaneous adverse reactions. The liver is the most commonly affected organ in DRESS, and kidney involvement can also occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Fixed drug eruption presents as well-defined, erythematous lesions that are often solitary and occur within 8 hours of drug exposure. The generalized morbilliform rash pattern and systemic organ involvement seen in this patient are not characteristic of fixed drug eruption.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically has an onset of 1-3 weeks after drug exposure and is characterized by bullous lesions, positive Nikolsky sign, and significant mucosal involvement. This patient's morbilliform rash pattern and lack of bullous lesions make Stevens-Johnson syndrome less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Exanthematous drug eruption presents as a morbilliform rash on the trunk and proximal extremities with typical onset 5-14 days after drug exposure. However, it does not typically involve facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, or internal organ involvement as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of skin lesions that began on her hands and feet. She reports fever and myalgia for 2 days. She denies recent medications. Examination shows lesions on the dorsal hands, feet, and forearms as shown. The patient has multiple painful oral ulcers affecting the buccal mucosa and tongue, causing difficulty with swallowing. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 92; R, 20; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Laboratory results show mild leukocytosis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with oral antihistamines and follow-up
Obtain dermatology consultation and skin biopsy
Start empiric antibiotic therapy for secondary infection
Admit for IV fluid therapy and systemic corticosteroids
Discontinue all medications and observe for 24 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's fever, systemic symptoms, and significant oral mucosal involvement causing dysphagia suggest erythema multiforme major. Outpatient management is inappropriate because monitoring and supportive care for fluid and nutritional needs are required.

B) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is not routinely indicated if a diagnosis of erythema multiforme can be made clinically based on the classic presentation of target lesions, recent herpes simplex virus infection, and the typical distribution pattern.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's leukocytosis is likely part of the inflammatory process rather than indicating bacterial superinfection. Empiric antibiotics are not indicated unless there are specific signs of secondary bacterial infection, such as purulent discharge or cellulitis.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has erythema multiforme major, evidenced by extensive target lesions, fever, systemic symptoms, and severe oral mucosal involvement. The painful oral ulcers and dysphagia indicate risk for dehydration and malnutrition, requiring hospitalization for IV fluid therapy and systemic corticosteroids to reduce mucosal inflammation.

E) INCORRECT:

While discontinuing medication is important in drug-induced eruptions, this patient's history of recent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and lack of recent medication use suggest HSV-triggered erythema multiforme. The severe mucosal involvement requires immediate treatment rather than observation.
